bioghist.p: Arthur Lindo Patterson (1902-1966) was a crystallographer who is best known for developing the Patterson function, an application of Fourier methods to X-ray diffraction. Patterson was born in New Zealand and educated at McGill University. He worked in many universities and research institutions, including the Royal Institution in London, the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute at Berlin-Dahlem, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. From 1940 until 1949 he was an associate professor at Bryn Mawr College. Beginning in 1949 he was senior member and head of the Department of Physics at the Institute for Cancer Research in Philadelphia. Patterson published numerous papers on X-ray analysis of crystal structures and was co-author, with W. C. Michels, of Elements of Modern Physics.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of A. Lindo Patterson. Materials include: correspondence; drafts of papers and related computations; newsletters and minutes from professional organizations, such as the American Crystallographic Association and the Crystallographic Society of America; correspondence and articles from symposia, such as meetings of the American Society for X-Ray and Electron Diffraction; computation books, research notes, graphs, technical drawings, and computer printouts of data; glass x-ray plates, x-ray film, and photographs; printing blocks of illustrations for articles; and lecture notes and exam questions from courses Patterson taught at Bryn Mawr College.
